Legal_Issue: Whether Health Canada's refusal to grant Wellesley Therapeutics permission to market disulfiram in Canada was legally justified under the Food and Drugs Act and Regulations
Application_Facts: Wellesley argued that disulfiram’s 50-year history in Canada established its safety and efficacy. Health Canada rejected this, citing insufficient evidence and requiring clinical trials.
Decision_Outcome: The court dismissed the DIN application (T-706-10) but allowed the NDS application (T-1537-07)
Remedy_Requested: Judicial review of Health Canada’s decisions
Court_Ruling: Health Canada must reconsider Wellesley’s NDS application considering all submissions and literature provided
Defendant_Behavior: Health Canada refused marketing permission and required clinical trial data despite long-standing use of disulfiram
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged unreasonable decision-making by Health Canada without proper analysis
Assessment_Factor: Sufficiency of evidence to establish safety and efficacy based on historical use
Procedural_Issue: Judicial review applications filed to challenge regulatory decisions
Evidence_Used: Affidavits, scientific literature, internal Health Canada documents
Legal_Provision_Cited: Definition of 'new drug' under the Food and Drugs Act
Application_Basis: Submission of a Notice of Compliance (NOC) with clinical trial data for a new drug
Evidence_Assessed: Historical use of disulfiram, clinical data, regulatory precedents
Relief_Sought: Reconsideration of NDS application and approval to market disulfiram
Governing_Rule: A drug is 'new' if not sold in Canada in sufficient quantity and duration to establish safety and efficacy; requires NOC after clinical data submission
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Health Canada cited lack of sufficient evidence despite long market history
Outcome: DIN application dismissed; NDS application remitted for reconsideration
Cause_Description: Wellesley sought approval to reintroduce disulfiram into the Canadian market after its previous withdrawal, leading to disputes over regulatory requirements
Evidence_Handling: Court found Health Canada failed to conduct substantive review of submitted literature and evidence
Evidence_Issues: Failure by Health Canada to properly analyze existing data and reliance on approvals of other drugs without justification
Legal_Provision: Food and Drugs Act, sections related to new drug definition and NOC requirements
Evidence_Assessment: Court assessed whether Health Canada reasonably evaluated the evidence
Decision_Rationale: Health Canada's rejection was unreasonable due to lack of substantive review and inadequate reasoning
Evidentiary_Issues: Insufficient consideration of long-term use data and external scientific literature
